menu.missionModeDesc: Historical progression starting in 1957. Unlock parts and technology as you advance through space history.
menu.sandboxModeDesc: All parts unlocked! Start in 2100 with full access to every technology.

chronology.title: SPACE CONQUEST
chronology.subtitle: CHRONOLOGY
chronology.selectEvent: Select an event to view details

sputnik1.title: Sputnik 1
sputnik1.desc: On October 4, 1957, the Soviet Union shocked the world by launching the first artificial satellite into orbit. The 58cm polished metal sphere transmitted radio pulses that could be picked up by amateur radio operators worldwide, proving that space was now within humanity's reach. This single launch triggered the Space Race and changed history forever.

sputnik2.title: Sputnik 2
sputnik2.desc: Just a month after Sputnik 1, the Soviets launched a much larger satellite carrying Laika, a stray dog from the streets of Moscow. Though Laika did not survive the mission, she proved that living organisms could endure the stresses of launch and weightlessness, paving the way for human spaceflight.

explorer1.title: Explorer 1
explorer1.desc: America's first satellite, designed by Wernher von Braun's team, launched on January 31, 1958. Aboard was a Geiger counter that made an unexpected discovery: intense radiation belts surrounding Earth. Scientist James Van Allen correctly interpreted the data, and the Van Allen Belts were named in his honor.

nasaFormed.title: NASA Formed
nasaFormed.desc: President Eisenhower signed the National Aeronautics and Space Act on July 29, 1958, creating NASA. The new agency absorbed NACA and unified America's space efforts under civilian control. This was crucial for the upcoming races to orbit and to the Moon.

luna2.title: Luna 2
luna2.desc: On September 14, 1959, Luna 2 became the first human-made object to reach the Moon, impacting in the Mare Imbrium. It carried Soviet pennants that scattered on impact. This mission proved that spacecraft could be accurately aimed at celestial bodies.

luna3.title: Luna 3
luna3.desc: In October 1959, Luna 3 flew around the Moon and photographed its far side for the first time in history. The images, developed onboard and transmitted back to Earth, revealed a surprisingly different terrain‚Äîmostly highlands with few 'seas'. Features were named after Soviet pioneers.

tiros1.title: TIROS-1
tiros1.desc: Launched April 1, 1960, TIROS-1 was the first successful weather satellite. During its 78 days of operation, it transmitted nearly 23,000 cloud cover images, revolutionizing weather forecasting. Meteorologists could now track hurricanes from space for the first time.

vostok1.title: Vostok 1
vostok1.desc: On April 12, 1961, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first human in space, completing one orbit of Earth in 108 minutes. His famous words, 'Poyekhali!' (Let's go!), marked the beginning of human space exploration. Gagarin became an international hero and symbol of the Space Age.

freedom7.title: Freedom 7
freedom7.desc: On May 5, 1961, Alan Shepard became the first American in space aboard Freedom 7. Though only a 15-minute suborbital flight, it demonstrated that Americans could also reach space. Shepard's courage under pressure made him a national hero and paved the way for the Mercury program.

friendship7.title: Friendship 7
friendship7.desc: John Glenn became the first American to orbit Earth on February 20, 1962. During his three orbits, a faulty sensor indicated his heat shield might be loose‚ÄîGlenn was told to leave the retrorocket pack attached during reentry. He survived, and the sensor turned out to be faulty.

vostok6.title: Vostok 6
vostok6.desc: Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman in space on June 16, 1963. The textile factory worker turned cosmonaut completed 48 orbits over nearly 3 days, orbiting more times than all American astronauts combined at that point. She remains the only woman to fly a solo space mission.

mariner4.title: Mariner 4
mariner4.desc: On July 15, 1965, Mariner 4 performed the first successful flyby of Mars, returning 22 close-up photos. The images revealed a cratered, Moon-like surface‚Äîshattering hopes of canals or vegetation. Mars was more desolate than expected, but the mission proved interplanetary exploration was possible.

voskhod2.title: Voskhod 2
voskhod2.desc: Alexei Leonov performed the first spacewalk on March 18, 1965, floating outside his spacecraft for 12 minutes. His suit inflated dangerously in the vacuum, and he had to partially deflate it to squeeze back through the airlock. Despite the drama, the mission proved humans could work in the void.

gemini4.title: Gemini 4
gemini4.desc: Ed White became the first American to walk in space on June 3, 1965. Using a handheld nitrogen gun for propulsion, he floated outside for 23 minutes. When ordered to return, he replied 'This is the saddest moment of my life.' White would later perish in the Apollo 1 fire.

luna9.title: Luna 9
luna9.desc: On February 3, 1966, Luna 9 became the first spacecraft to achieve a soft landing on the Moon. The 99 kg lander transmitted the first panoramic photos from the lunar surface, proving the surface was solid‚Äînot the deep dust some had feared would swallow landers.

gemini8.title: Gemini 8
gemini8.desc: Neil Armstrong and David Scott achieved the first docking of two spacecraft on March 16, 1966, connecting with an Agena target vehicle. When a stuck thruster sent them into a dangerous spin, Armstrong coolly used reentry thrusters to regain control. This presaged his calm under pressure on Apollo 11.

apollo1.title: Apollo 1 Fire
apollo1.desc: On January 27, 1967, a flash fire swept through the Apollo 1 capsule during a launch pad test, killing astronauts Gus Grissom, Ed White, and Roger Chaffee. The pure oxygen atmosphere and flammable materials turned the cabin into a death trap. NASA completely redesigned the spacecraft.

saturnv.title: Saturn V
saturnv.desc: The first all-up test of the Saturn V on November 9, 1967 was a complete success. At 111 meters tall and 2,800 tons, it remains the most powerful rocket ever flown. Its five F-1 engines produced 7.5 million pounds of thrust. This monster would carry humans to the Moon.

apollo8.title: Apollo 8
apollo8.desc: In December 1968, Frank Borman, Jim Lovell, and Bill Anders became the first humans to leave Earth orbit and reach the Moon. On Christmas Eve, they read from Genesis while viewing Earth rise over the lunar horizon‚Äîan image that changed how humanity saw itself.

apollo11.title: Apollo 11
apollo11.desc: On July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed the Eagle on the Sea of Tranquility while Michael Collins orbited above. Armstrong's first words on the surface, 'That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind,' are etched in history. They spent 2.5 hours exploring the lunar surface.

salyut1.title: Salyut 1
salyut1.desc: The first space station was launched on April 19, 1971. Though the first crew couldn't enter due to a docking hatch problem, the second crew (Soyuz 11) spent 23 days aboard. Tragically, they died during reentry due to a valve failure. Their sacrifice led to mandatory pressure suits during launch and landing.

skylab.title: Skylab
skylab.desc: America's first space station launched on May 14, 1973, modified from a Saturn V upper stage. Despite losing its primary solar panel and heat shield during launch, three crews performed daring repairs and conducted 270 days of science. Skylab proved humans could live in space for months.

apolloSoyuz.title: Apollo-Soyuz
apolloSoyuz.desc: In July 1975, American astronauts and Soviet cosmonauts rendezvoused and docked in orbit‚Äîthe first international crewed space mission. Tom Stafford and Alexei Leonov shook hands through the hatch, symbolizing detente during the Cold War. This mission pioneered techniques used on the ISS.

viking1.title: Viking 1
viking1.desc: On July 20, 1976‚Äîexactly seven years after Apollo 11‚ÄîViking 1 became the first US spacecraft to land on Mars. It transmitted the first color photos from the Martian surface and searched for signs of life. The results were ambiguous but tantalizing.

voyager1.title: Voyager 1
voyager1.desc: Launched September 5, 1977, Voyager 1 used gravity assists to visit Jupiter and Saturn before heading toward interstellar space. Its Golden Record carries greetings in 55 languages and music from around the world. In 2012, it became the first human-made object to enter interstellar space.

pioneerVenus.title: Pioneer Venus
pioneerVenus.desc: In 1978, Pioneer Venus sent an orbiter and four atmospheric probes to Earth's 'evil twin'. The data revealed Venus's crushing 90-atmosphere surface pressure, 460¬∞C temperatures, and sulfuric acid clouds. One probe survived 67 minutes on the hostile surface.

sts1.title: STS-1 Columbia
sts1.desc: On April 12, 1981‚Äîexactly 20 years after Gagarin‚ÄîJohn Young and Bob Crippen launched aboard Columbia, the first Space Shuttle. Unlike all previous spacecraft, the Shuttle was designed to be reusable, landing like an airplane. This began a 30-year era of Shuttle operations.

challenger.title: Challenger Disaster
challenger.desc: On January 28, 1986, Space Shuttle Challenger broke apart 73 seconds after launch, killing all seven crew members including teacher Christa McAuliffe. The cause was an O-ring seal failure in cold weather. The disaster led to a 32-month hiatus and major safety reforms.

mir.title: Mir Space Station
mir.desc: The Soviet Union launched the Mir core module on February 19, 1986, beginning a 15-year mission. Mir pioneered modular station construction and hosted international astronauts. Despite fires, collisions, and aging systems, it proved humanity could maintain a permanent presence in space.

galileo.title: Galileo
galileo.desc: Launched in 1989, Galileo arrived at Jupiter in 1995 and spent 8 years studying the giant planet and its moons. Its atmospheric probe survived 58 minutes in Jupiter's atmosphere. Most importantly, it found strong evidence for a subsurface ocean on Europa.

hubble.title: Hubble Space Telescope
hubble.desc: Launched April 24, 1990, Hubble was initially hampered by a flawed mirror. After a dramatic repair mission in 1993, it became arguably the most important telescope in history, transforming our understanding of the universe from exoplanets to the age of the cosmos.

pathfinder.title: Mars Pathfinder
pathfinder.desc: On July 4, 1997, Pathfinder bounced to a landing on Mars using innovative airbags. Its tiny rover Sojourner‚Äîthe first Mars rover‚Äîexplored nearby rocks for 83 days. The mission proved low-cost planetary exploration was possible and captivated the public.

issZarya.title: ISS Zarya Module
issZarya.desc: The first component of the International Space Station launched on November 20, 1998. This Russian-built module was followed by the US Unity node just weeks later. The ISS would become the largest structure ever built in space, hosting astronauts from 19 countries.

spaceshipone.title: SpaceShipOne
spaceshipone.desc: On October 4, 2004, SpaceShipOne won the $10 million Ansari X Prize by completing two flights above 100km within two weeks. Designed by Burt Rutan and funded by Paul Allen, it proved private companies could reach space‚Äîlaunching the NewSpace revolution.

falcon1.title: Falcon 1 Success
falcon1.desc: After three failures, SpaceX's Falcon 1 finally reached orbit on September 28, 2008. The company was nearly bankrupt‚Äîthis was their last chance. The Merlin engine design proved itself, and Elon Musk's gamble paid off. SpaceX would go on to transform the industry.

dragonCargo.title: Dragon Cargo
dragonCargo.desc: On December 8, 2010, SpaceX's Dragon capsule became the first commercial spacecraft to be recovered from orbit. In 2012, it became the first commercial craft to dock with the ISS. The PICA-X heat shield and cargo capability marked a new era in space logistics.

curiosity.title: Curiosity Rover
curiosity.desc: On August 6, 2012, the car-sized Curiosity rover landed on Mars using an audacious sky crane maneuver. Its nuclear power source enables year-round operation. Curiosity found ancient riverbeds and organic molecules, proving Mars was once habitable.

falcon9.title: Falcon 9 Landing
falcon9.desc: On December 21, 2015, a Falcon 9 first stage landed vertically at Cape Canaveral after delivering satellites to orbit‚Äîthe first orbital-class rocket to achieve propulsive landing. This breakthrough slashed launch costs and made SpaceX the dominant launch provider.

starlink.title: Starlink Constellation
starlink.desc: SpaceX launched the first 60 Starlink satellites on May 23, 2019, beginning construction of the largest satellite constellation in history. Using krypton ion thrusters and phased-array antennas, Starlink aims to provide global broadband internet from over 40,000 satellites.

crewDragon.title: Crew Dragon
crewDragon.desc: On May 30, 2020, NASA astronauts Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley launched aboard SpaceX's Crew Dragon‚Äîthe first commercial human spaceflight to orbit. This ended NASA's dependence on Russian Soyuz and began a new era of commercial crew transportation to the ISS.

jamesWebb.title: James Webb Space Telescope
jamesWebb.desc: Launched December 25, 2021, JWST deployed its 6.5-meter gold mirror and tennis-court-sized sunshield flawlessly. Operating at L2 point, it has revealed the earliest galaxies, detected atmospheres of exoplanets, and captured stunning images of nearby star-forming regions.

artemis1.title: Artemis I
artemis1.desc: On November 16, 2022, NASA's SLS rocket launched the Orion capsule on a 25-day mission around the Moon. This uncrewed test proved the most powerful rocket since Saturn V and the heat shield for lunar-return velocities. Artemis marks humanity's return to deep space.

starshipOrbital.title: Starship Orbital Test
starshipOrbital.desc: SpaceX's fully reusable Starship‚Äîthe largest rocket ever flown‚Äîachieved its first successful orbital test in 2024. With 33 Raptor engines producing twice Saturn V's thrust, Starship is designed to carry 100+ passengers to Mars and enable permanent human settlement beyond Earth.

artemis3.title: Artemis III
artemis3.desc: The first crewed lunar landing since 1972, Artemis III will land astronauts near the lunar south pole using SpaceX's Starship HLS. For the first time, a woman and person of color will walk on the Moon. This mission establishes sustainable lunar exploration.

lunarGateway.title: Lunar Gateway
lunarGateway.desc: The Lunar Gateway is a small space station orbiting the Moon in a near-rectilinear halo orbit. It serves as a staging point for lunar surface missions and deep space exploration. International partners contribute modules for habitation, propulsion, and science.

marsSample.title: Mars Sample Return
marsSample.desc: A NASA-ESA collaboration retrieves samples cached by the Perseverance rover and launches them from Mars using the first rocket ever launched from another planet. These pristine samples are analyzed in Earth laboratories, potentially revealing ancient Martian life.

lunarBase.title: Artemis Base Camp
lunarBase.desc: The first permanent lunar base is established near the south pole's Shackleton Crater, where water ice exists in permanently shadowed regions. ISRU systems extract water for life support and rocket fuel. Crews stay for 60-day rotations, conducting science and testing Mars technologies.

marsHumans.title: First Humans on Mars
marsHumans.desc: After months of transit, the first crew of explorers sets foot on Mars. They establish a habitat in Jezero Crater, surrounded by ancient river delta deposits. Using ISRU to produce fuel and oxygen from the Martian atmosphere, they begin humanity's era as a multiplanetary species.

phobosStation.title: Phobos Station
phobosStation.desc: An outpost is established on Phobos, Mars's larger moon. Its low gravity makes it ideal for refueling and staging Mars surface missions. Researchers study the moon's enigmatic origins‚Äîis it a captured asteroid or debris from ancient Mars?

marsStation.title: Mars Orbital Station
marsStation.desc: A permanent station in Mars orbit enables regular crew rotations, real-time surface operations support, and interplanetary ship maintenance. Cycler spacecraft begin regular Earth-Mars transits, cutting travel time and radiation exposure.

lunarCity.title: Lunar City
lunarCity.desc: The lunar base expands to support 1,000 permanent residents. Lava tubes provide radiation protection for agriculture domes. Mass drivers launch construction materials to orbital facilities. The Moon becomes humanity's first off-world industrial hub.

marsCity.title: Mars City
marsCity.desc: The first true Martian city reaches 1,000 residents living in pressurized habitats. Nuclear reactors provide power, while ISRU facilities produce all life support. Children born on Mars‚Äîthe first true Martians‚Äîgrow up never knowing Earth gravity.

asteroidMining.title: Asteroid Mining Begins
asteroidMining.desc: Robotic mining operations begin on near-Earth asteroids, harvesting water, platinum-group metals, and raw materials. These resources fuel a space-based economy, dropping the cost of space construction by orders of magnitude.

europaProbe.title: Europa Lander
europaProbe.desc: After years of development, a probe lands on Europa's ice shell and drills toward the subsurface ocean. Protected from Jupiter's murderous radiation by a specially designed vault, it searches for signs of life in one of the solar system's most promising habitats.

callisto.title: Callisto Base
callisto.desc: A research outpost is established on Callisto, just outside Jupiter's most intense radiation belts. From this relatively safe haven, scientists operate probes exploring the Jovian system and prepare technologies for eventual Europa ocean exploration.

fusionEngine.title: Fusion Engine Breakthrough
fusionEngine.desc: Practical fusion propulsion becomes reality, enabling spacecraft to reach Mars in weeks instead of months, and the outer solar system in years instead of decades. Helium-3 mining on the Moon provides fuel for this new era of rapid interplanetary travel.

titanColony.title: Titan Colony
titanColony.desc: An outpost is established on Saturn's moon Titan, the only moon with a thick atmosphere. Despite -180¬∞C temperatures, the dense nitrogen atmosphere provides radiation protection and enables flight with simple wings. Methane lakes fuel local operations.

marsOcean.title: Mars Terraforming Begins
marsOcean.desc: After decades of industrial activity, Mars's atmosphere begins to thicken measurably. Orbital mirrors concentrate sunlight on the poles, releasing CO2. It's a project measured in centuries, but the first steps toward a second blue-green world have begun.

interstellarProbe.title: Interstellar Probe
interstellarProbe.desc: The first interstellar probe accelerates toward Alpha Centauri using a powerful Earth-based laser array pushing a lightsail. Though it will take decades to arrive and transmit data back, humanity has finally reached for the stars.

dysonSwarm.title: Dyson Swarm Construction
dysonSwarm.desc: Thousands of solar collectors begin orbiting the Sun, beaming power to receivers throughout the solar system. Though far from a complete sphere, this partial Dyson Swarm marks humanity's transition to a Type I civilization.

proxima.title: Proxima Centauri Mission
proxima.desc: The first crewed interstellar mission launches toward Proxima Centauri b, the nearest known exoplanet in a habitable zone. Using antimatter propulsion, the generation ship will take decades to arrive, carrying thousands of colonists to humanity's first extrasolar world.
